title: Add a meaningful audit event name for `remove_source_branch_after_merge` in Project
description:
### Problem to solve

Some audit events are named `audit_operation`. This isn't a descriptive name and makes it difficult to differentiated from other events.

Additional context is available in this [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8497) and in the parent [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8057).

### Proposal

Add a meaningful `name` for the `remove_source_branch_after_merge` audit event's update action that can be used to differentiate it from other events.

Naming should follow the `noun_verb` format and use the past tense. For example `ci_variable_created`.

For events created with `audit_changes` we can pass the event name using the `event_type` argument.

```rb
audit_changes(:email, as: 'email address', event_type: 'email_address_added')
```

Also consider [this MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/92074) as an example of how to do this.

### Implementation plan

1. Add an meaningful event `name` to the `remove_source_branch_after_merge` event in this [file](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/lib/ee/audit/project_changes_auditor.rb).
   - The name should follow the `noun_verb` format.
1. Update the associated specs is required.

## Notes

- [For instructions on how to setup your development environment.](https://about.gitlab.com/community/contribute/development/#setup-the-development-enviroment)
- For any questions regarding audit events reach out to a member of the [compliance group](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/dev/manage/compliance/#group-members).

title: Prevent preloading `last_deployment`/`last_visible_deployment`/`upcoming_deployment` with a legacy approach
description:
## Problem

Originally, pointed out by @bala.kumar in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/83558#note_895662565.

We have `Preloaders::Environments::DeploymentPreloader` to preload `last_deployment`/`last_visible_deployment` correctly and efficiently, however, technically we can still use the legacy preload approach such as `resource.preload({last_deployment: deployment_associations})`, which could read data wrongly and inefficiently. We should prevent us from using the legacy approach.

## Context discussion thread

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/83558#note_895662565

>>>
**Possible solution:**

1. Introduce argument to the lambda scope of association so direct preloading is not possible as mentioned in https://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/Associations/ClassMethods.html

> Note: Joining, eager loading and preloading of these associations is not possible. These operations happen before instance creation and the scope will be called with a nil argument.

```ruby
  # Introducing association argument to prevent direct preloading.
  # Consider using Preloaders::Environments::DeploymentPreloader.new.execute_with_union instead.
  has_one :last_deployment, -> (environments) { success.ordered }, class_name: 'Deployment', inverse_of: :environment
```

1. Or even better consider moving `last_deployment` to a model class method instead of an association.
>>>

### Proposal
1) Introduce argument to the lambda scope of association so direct preloading is not possible.
2) Moving the associations to class method results in ` ActiveRecord::AssociationNotFoundError: Association named 'last_deployment' was not found on Environment;` and to avoid it we will have to do further refactor to existing code areas. If required we can create a low priority issue to capture this work in the future and it can be worked on once the [serializer fragility epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8433) is closed as some of these associations may not be required then.

### POC
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/97963/diffs

title: Assess accuracy of semver_dialects using gemnasium/vrange
description:
### Problem to solve

We'd like to use [semver_dialects](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/vulnerability-research/foss/semver_dialects)
to implement Continuous Scanning in the backend,
and to support all the languages and package managers Gemnasium (Dependency Scanning) supports today.
However, `semver_dialects` might not be as accurate as Gemnasium's [vrange](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/tree/master/vrange) library,
and this might result in false positives and false negatives.
See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/363073#note_970572115

### Proposal

Leverage [gemnasium-db](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/gemnasium-db) to compare `semver_dialects` to `vrange`, report discrepancies, and create follow-up issues to address them.

For each YAML file of `gemnasium-db`, do the following:

1. Query the package registry to list package versions.
1. Find affected, fixed, and non-affected versions using `gemnasium/vrange`.
1. Find affected, fixed, and non-affected versions using `semver_dialects`.
1. Report inconsistencies.

We can either query the API of the package registry or use the package manager to list the versions of a package.

To find the affected and non-affected versions, go through the versions listed on the package registry, and evaluate the `affected_range` of the YAML file.

Also, find package versions that match the `fixed_versions` of the YAML file.

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/220286#note_1044076127

### Implementation plan

The proposal above is likely the best way to do an assessment of the `semver_dialects` gem. The solution will also allow our team to facilitate https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369239+.

- [x] add vrange [command](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/master/cmd/gemnasium/main.go#L69) to gemnasium allowing queries given a range and a version
- [x] create a project for running this test
  - ruby optimal here since `semver_dialects` is a ruby gem and this matching capability will be used in the rails monolith
- [x] check out advisory db
- [x] iterate over each package manager directory (e.g. `pypi`, `gem`)
  - iterate over each directory corresponding to a package
    - get list of official versions for package (to simplify configuration try to use docker as much as possible; this can be used in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369239+ under docker-dind image)
    - iterate over each advisory
      - check `version` of package against `advisory.affected_range`
        - using `vrange`
        - using `semver_dialects`
      - [x] capture matches, mismatches and which range functionality they belong to using a greppable format
        - capture to db that can be saved to disk and queries via `jq` (for example)
- [x] commit code used to generate this check to make it repeatable for new semver types - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/semver-assessment
- [x] report results - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369238#note_1114975584
- [ ] create follow-up issues

/cc @julianthome @bwill

epic.title: Trigger vulnerability scans on SBOM or advisory changes

title: Merge request changes tab fails to load, errors with - TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'push')
description:
### Summary

This entry was discovered in Sentry based on a customer report that if they attempt to view changes via the [Merge Request Changes tab](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/changes.html#show-all-changes-in-a-merge-request) in specific MRs, within a specific project, they'll just see the loading spinner endlessly and the changes never appear. 

It is still possible to use the API to [Get Single MR changes](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/merge_requests.html#get-single-mr-changes) and view diff details this way, but this may not be a reasonable workaround for users experiencing this issue.

- Customer [Zendesk ticket _(internal use only)_](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/312602)
- Sentry Issue: [GITLABCOM-CLIENTSIDE-3K76](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom-clientside/issues/2809205/events/106570252/)

    ```
    TypeError?(/assets/webpack/tree_worker.e27039d2.worker.js)
    Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'push')
    ```

There are also similar looking Sentry issues available for a different customer project:

- [https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom-clientside/issues/2809205/events/106552236/](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom-clientside/issues/2809205/events/106552236/)

### What is the current _bug_ behavior?

The [Merge Request Changes tab](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/changes.html#show-all-changes-in-a-merge-request) will not load any of the expected content and appears to be stuck.

It seems to occur when there is a directory named `constructor` in the repo root

### What is the expected _correct_ behavior?

The [Merge Request Changes tab](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/changes.html#show-all-changes-in-a-merge-request) should load the related MR changes as expected.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

The developer console output within the user's browser will output the same error that is being logged into Sentry:

`Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'push')`

title: Remove GraphQL `feature_flag` property
description:
## About

We currently have 2 methods of using feature flags in GraphQL:

- `feature_flag` property ([doc](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/api_graphql_styleguide.html#feature_flag-property)).
- Toggle the value/behaviour with a feature flag ([doc](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/api_graphql_styleguide.html#toggle-the-value-of-a-field)).

We also have a related `alpha` property ([doc](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/api_graphql_styleguide.html#marking-schema-items-as-alpha)) that marks the item as `@deprecated` and appends the description with a notice that it should not be used. 

## Problem

`feature_flag` has always had a problem where when the flag is toggled on, the field is "released", even though the flag can be toggled off again. 

We [currently advise](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d04230de211dca843ecfeec0d1645611b18768a2/doc/development/api_graphql_styleguide.md#frontend-and-backend-feature-flag-strategies) not to use `feature_flag` when following our [frontend best-practice](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/d04230de211dca843ecfeec0d1645611b18768a2/doc/development/fe_guide/graphql.md#the-include-directive).

It's been raised that having 2 methods of feature flagging items, plus a new related `alpha` property, is confusing.

## Proposal

There's an opportunity to remove `feature_flag`, and consolidate these items to:

- Toggle the value/behaviour with a feature flag.
- `alpha`

These two allow for these scenarios:

| Scenario | header |
| ------ | ------ |
| New volatile schema item with a flag | Toggle + `alpha` |
| New volatile schema item with no flag | `alpha` |
| New stable schema item with a flag | Toggle |
| New stable schema item with no flag | - |

We would replace all current usage of `feature_flag` with a value/behaviour toggle behind a flag + mark the field as `alpha` if the flag is disabled by default.

We will need to update `RuboCop::Cop::Gitlab::MarkUsedFeatureFlags` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369202#note_1047189351.

title: Remove WorkItemUpdateWidgets mutation
description:
`WorkItemUpdateWidgets` was originally introduced as the result of a conversation about making mutation smaller and more specific during the first work item widgets implementation.

Now we are only using a more general mutation `WorkItemUpdate` to update all widgets and other fields of a work item. 

~frontend still uses the `WorkItemUpdateWidgets` mutation to update descriptions. We should use the  more generic `workItemUpdate` mutation and on the next milestone remove the mutation from the API.

The mutation is still behind a feature flag and also marked as experimental, so we shouldn't follow the regular deprecation process to remove it, no external client should be using it.

title: Use `DestroyBatchService` in `Ci::Build#erase`
description:
Currently, `Ci::Build#erase` uses [`job_artifacts.destroy_all`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/models/ci/build.rb#L830) to delete all artifacts within the build.

Given the intricacies of artifact deletion, we should avoid having multiple ways to delete a batch of artifacts and have a single service that handles this. We already have `Ci::JobArtifacts::DestroyBatchService` so let's use this here as well instead of `destroy_all`.

title: Standard way to return mutation errors. Null or unchanged object
Backend: Remove `masked` and `protected` from the VariableInterface and add to Types instead.
description:
Follow-up from: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/362934#note_1040614360

The `Variable` interface has the `masked` and `protected` fields. However, these fields aren't available for pipeline variables. So they should be moved into `CiProjectVariableType`, `CiInstanceVariableType`, and `CiGroupVariableType`

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `ci_new_public_oss_cost_factor`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/351933) on production,
that is currently behind the `ci_new_public_oss_cost_factor` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Pipeline Execution
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_pipeline_execution`
- Best individual to reach out to: @allison.browne 
- PM: @jheimbuck_gl  

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

### When is the feature viable?

<!-- What are the settings we need to configure in order to have this feature viable? -->

<!-- 
Example below:
 
1. Enable service ping collection
   `ApplicationSetting.first.update(usage_ping_enabled: true)`
-->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_new_public_oss_cost_factor true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com ci_new_public_oss_cost_factor true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
- [x] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_pipeline_execution`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_new_public_oss_cost_factor true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/351933) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `ci_new_public_oss_cost_factor` feature flag. 
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
    - [x] Ask for review and merge it.
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run release check 9cc487cf`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/351933) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status 9cc487cf6944f15423f5cc94dd965ec37c1dd37f`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete ci_new_public_oss_cost_factor --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set ci_new_public_oss_cost_factor false
```

title: Migrate `gitlab-org` to the new registry
description:
## Context

This is part of the work to upgrade and migrate the GitLab.com container registry to a new version backed by a metadata database and online garbage collection (https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5523). This will be achieved following the gradual migration plan detailed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/container-registry/-/issues/374.

The migration is now 90%+ complete, with just a few customers AND `gitlab-org` left. This issue is to plan, coordinate and execute the migration of all `gitlab-org` container repositories that exist on the old Container Registry platform to the new one.

## Data

Available in [this](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Uf2jhpQnAE-aYOgT--qFoUEXV0S_HM5sM_REPGr3_sE/edit?usp=sharing) spreadsheet, including:

* List of all repositories;
* Current tag count for each repository;
* Estimated* pre-import (read/write allowed) duration;
* Estimated* final import (read-only) duration;
* Top 10 repositories in overall activity during the last 7 days and the last weekend;
* Same as above but for write activity only.

<sub>* Estimate based on the observed duration for a sample of recently migrated VIP repositories. The actual duration for each `gitlab-org` repository may vary.</sub>

### Highlights

* 3345 repositories in total;
* Only 227 have more than 100 tags;
* Only 84 have more than 1k tags;
* Only 13 have more than 10k tags;
* The largest is `gitlab-org/gitlab/gitlab-ee-qa`, with 34k tags;
* The majority of large (20k+ tags) repositories are under `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror`;
* Only 11 repositories are *expected* to require more than 5 minutes for the final import step (where we block writes). None is expected to take more than 10 minutes;
* 3282 out of 3345 (\~98%) are expected to require less than 30 seconds for the final import step. 30 seconds is the time that the Docker client will keep retrying an image push in case the request is rejected. So, in theory, CI pipelines trying to push images to these repositories *while* they are being migrated would eventually succeed without needing to be manually retried;
* All the 13 largest (10k+ tags) repositories have identical usage patterns with low to no write activity during weekends.

### Largest repositories (10k+ tags)

| Path | Tags | Estimated pre-import duration (read/write) | Estimated final import duration (read-only) |
|------|------|--------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
| `gitlab-org/gitlab/gitlab-ee-qa` | 34323 | 23:50:08 | 00:08:35 |
| `gitlab-org/gitlab/gitlab-assets-ee` | 32047 | 22:15:18 | 00:08:01 |
| `gitlab-org/build/omnibus-gitlab-mirror/gitlab-ee` | 30159 | 20:56:38 | 00:07:32 |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-geo-logcursor` | 29315 | 20:21:28 | 00:07:20 |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-rails-ee` | 29310 | 20:21:15 | 00:07:20 |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-sidekiq-ee` | 29299 | 20:20:48 | 00:07:19 |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-workhorse-ee` | 29291 | 20:20:28 | 00:07:19 |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-webservice-ee` | 28762 | 19:58:25 | 00:07:11 |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-shell` | 28627 | 19:52:48 | 00:07:09 |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-toolbox-ee` | 28219 | 19:35:48 | 00:07:03 |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-pages` | 24493 | 17:00:33 | 00:06:07 |
| `gitlab-org/gitlab-runner/gitlab-runner-helper` | 13473 | 09:21:23 | 00:03:22 |
| `gitlab-org/build/omnibus-gitlab-mirror/gitlab-ee-qa` | 12631 | 08:46:18 | 00:03:09 |

## Plan

1. Migrate all 13 repositories above 10k tags across two weekends. None is expected to take more than 24h to fully migrate (pre+final import), and the system can migrate up to 40 in parallel. So we could do it all in a single weekend. However:
   * These are likely the most critical ones for internal operations;
   * Mainly: some of these repositories are responsible for a non-negligible share of the overall registry API traffic. I don't like the idea of shifting that load from the old to the new registry in one go.
1. Migrate the remaining 3332 in no specific order (randomly picked) from Tuesday to Thursday in the weekdays between the two weekends above. This gives us a "silent" period of 24h on Monday and Friday (while everyone is around) to detect and react to any problems. Technically, at the maximum capacity (40), we could migrate all of them in a couple of hours. Still, we can reduce capacity to slow things down for additional peace of mind (being overcautious).

### Communication

* Reach out to the team(s) that own the largest repositories to let them know about the migration and see if there are any concerns about doing it on a specific weekend;
* Post on `#whats-happening-at-gitlab` before starting the migration of the remaining 3332 during the week. This is for awareness and to give people a point of contact (`#f_container-registry`) in case they see something odd;

The migration is at 94%, with over 1.5M repositories done by now, so I think we don't need something special here.

#### FAQ

##### Can we anticipate when the read-only period will occur for a specific repository?

No. It can happen at any time during the defined migration window.

##### What happens if we have pipelines attempting to push images to a repository while it's being migrated?

Pushes will succeed as usual during the vast majority of the migration time (read/write period), they will only be blocked for the duration of the last portion (read-only period).

If using Docker (likely), the client will keep retrying for up to 30s. If the repository remains locked against writes for longer, you'll need to retry the failed pipelines.

See the `Data` section for the estimated time to migrate each of the largest repositories. See the [spreadsheet]((https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Uf2jhpQnAE-aYOgT--qFoUEXV0S_HM5sM_REPGr3_sE/edit?usp=sharing)) for all others.

##### Can we pull images from repositories while they are being migrated?

Yes. Pulls should continue to succeed, even during the last portion of the migration (where we block writes). Once the migration is complete, reads are redirected to the new registry. This is fully transparent, so you won't notice anything different (except that some requests will be faster).

### Schedule

#### Largest

| Path | Owner | Date | Done | 
|------|------|--------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------|
| `gitlab-org/gitlab/gitlab-ee-qa` | ~"team::Quality Engineering" | ~~August 20-21~~ September 10-11 |  |
| `gitlab-org/build/omnibus-gitlab-mirror/gitlab-ee` | ~"Distribution:Build"  | August 20-21 | :white_check_mark: | 
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-geo-logcursor` | ~"Distribution:Build" | August 20-21 | :white_check_mark: |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-sidekiq-ee` | ~"Distribution:Build" | ~~August 20-21~~ September 10-11 |  |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-toolbox-ee` | ~"Distribution:Build" | August 20-21 | :white_check_mark: |
| `gitlab-org/gitlab-runner/gitlab-runner-helper` | ~"group::runner" | August 20-21 | :white_check_mark: |
| `gitlab-org/gitlab/gitlab-assets-ee` | ~"Engineering Productivity"  | August 27-28 | :white_check_mark: | 
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-rails-ee` | ~"Distribution:Build" | August 27-28 | :white_check_mark: |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-workhorse-ee` | ~"Distribution:Build" | August 27-28 | :white_check_mark: | 
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-webservice-ee` | ~"Distribution:Build" | ~~August 27-28~~ September 10-11 |  |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-shell` | ~"Distribution:Build" | August 27-28 | :white_check_mark: |
| `gitlab-org/build/cng-mirror/gitlab-pages` | ~"Distribution:Build"  | August 27-28 | :white_check_mark: |
| `gitlab-org/build/omnibus-gitlab-mirror/gitlab-ee-qa` | ~"Distribution:Build" | ~~August 27-28~~ September 10-11 |  |

#### Remaining

August 23-25.

## Execution Plan

#### August 20

- [x] ~"group::package" increases the GC review delay from 24h to 48h (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/k8s-workloads/gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/2055)

- [x] ~"group::package" enables the migration (if not already) and adds a comment to the [rollout issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350543):

  ```
  /chatops run feature set container_registry_migration_phase2_enabled true
  ```

  Note that there is no need to adjust the tag count limit or the deny list, as we're bypassing the Rails enqueuer worker where those are validated.

- [x] ~"team::Delivery" executes the [change request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7583) to kickoff the migration of repositories scheduled for this weekend.

- [x] ~"group::package" occasionally checks the migration [logs](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/14fcfd60-1a55-11ed-8656-f5f2137823ba) (diving into the correlation ID for any specific pre/final import if needed) and [metrics](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/registry-migration/registry-migration-detail?orgId=1&from=now-1h&to=now) to monitor progress. As an alternative or as a complement, query the registry database directly to see the list of repositories (pre)import[ing|ed] during the day, including the number of (pre)imported tags for each:

  <details><summary>Click to see query</summary>

  ```sql
  SELECT
      r.top_level_namespace_id,
      r.id,
      r.path,
      r.migration_status,
      r.created_at,
      r.updated_at,
      (
          SELECT
              COUNT(*)
          FROM
              tags AS t
          WHERE
              t.top_level_namespace_id = r.top_level_namespace_id
              AND t.repository_id = r.id) AS tag_count
  FROM
      repositories AS r
  WHERE (date_trunc('day', r.updated_at) = date_trunc('day', now())
      OR date_trunc('day', r.created_at) = date_trunc('day', now()))
  AND r.path LIKE 'gitlab-org/%'
  AND r.migration_status <> 'native'
  ORDER BY
      updated_at ASC;
  ```
  </details>

#### August 21

- [x] ~"group::package" checks the migration logs and metrics. All repositories should have been imported by now.

#### August 22

- [x] ~"group::package" reverts the increase of the GC review delay from 24h to 48h (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/k8s-workloads/gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/2055)

- [x] ~"group::package" stays alert for any reported issues with the migrated repositories. No additional `gitlab-org` repositories should be migrated during this day.

- [x] ~"group::package" posts a message on `#whats-happening-at-gitlab`, `#development` and [Eng Week in Review](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JBdCl3MAOSdlgq3kzzRmtzTsFWsTIQ9iQg0RHhMht6E/edit#) to let people know about the upcoming bulk migration (August 23-25). Link this issue for additional information and direct people to `#f_container_registry` for reporting any potentially related issue.


```
We will be migrating most of the container registry repositories under `gitlab-org` throughout Aug 23-25.
The whole process should be seamless, however, there is a slight chance pushing new images to some of those repositories will fail as there is a short read-only period while a given repository is being migrated.
If a push fails, it is advised to wait a few minutes before retrying. Once the migration is done, you shouldn't have any issues but if you do, please reach out to #f_container_registry. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369101  for more details.
```

- [x]  ~~`team::Delivery` executes the [change request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7605) to manually skip the repositories that should only be migrated on the 2nd weekend (August 27-28). This is needed to ensure these repositories won't be picked up automatically during the weekend migration.~~ Edit: This was done ahead of time (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369101#note_1068291345), so the plan has changed, with an additional step on August 23.

#### August 23

- [x] ~"group::package" drops the concurrent capacity from `40` to `5` (to slowdown the migration pace and make it last a couple of days) and adds a comment to the [rollout issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350543):

  ```
  /chatops run feature set container_registry_migration_phase2_capacity_40 false
  /chatops run feature set container_registry_migration_phase2_capacity_25 false
  /chatops run feature set container_registry_migration_phase2_capacity_10 false
  /chatops run feature set container_registry_migration_phase2_capacity_5 true
  ```

- [x] ~"group::package" confirms that the previously skipped repositories (those reserved for the 2nd weekend) in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7605 are still marked as skipped. This can be done by looking at the count of repositories skipped due to `Not in plan` in [this graph](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/registry-migration/registry-migration-detail?orgId=1&from=now-1h&to=now&viewPanel=149). The value must be `7`. Otherwise, https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7605 need to be re-executed before proceeding.

- [x] ~"group::package" removes `gitlab-org` from the deny list (to make the remaining repositories eligible for migration) and adds a comment to the [rollout issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350543):

  ```
  /chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org container_registry_phase_2_deny_list false
  ```

- [x] ~"group::package" monitors the migration progress.

- [x] ~"group::package" adjusts concurrent capacity based on the observed [hourly import rate](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/registry-migration/registry-migration-detail?orgId=1&from=now-3h&to=now&viewPanel=148) and the number of remaining `gitlab-org` repositories to be migrated. The intent is to spread the migration across August 23, 24, and 25, if possible.

#### August 24

- [x] ~"group::package" monitors the migration progress;
- [x] ~"group::package" asks ~"team::Delivery" to review and schedule the [change request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7588) for the second batch (for the weekend of 27-28).

#### August 25

- [x] ~"group::package" monitors the migration progress.
- [x] ~"group::package" creates change request to retry any failed imports due to transitient errors (if any) and asks ~"team::Delivery" to review and execute ([sample](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7134)). -> https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7334+

#### August 26

- [x] ~"group::package" checks the migration status. All repositories should have been imported by now. No additional `gitlab-org` repositories should be migrated (besides failures from previous days, if any) during this day;

- [x] ~"group::package" increases the GC review delay from 24h to 48h (identical to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/k8s-workloads/gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/2055) late in the day. -> https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/k8s-workloads/gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/2075

#### August 27

- [x] ~"group::package" enables the migration (if not already) and adds a comment to the [rollout issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/350543):

  ```
  /chatops run feature set container_registry_migration_phase2_enabled true
  ```

- [x] ~"team::Delivery" executes the [change request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/7588) to kick off the migration of repositories scheduled for this weekend.

- [x] ~"group::package" occasionally checks the migration logs and metrics to monitor progress.

#### August 28

- [x] ~"group::package" checks the migration logs and metrics. All repositories should have been imported by now.

#### August 29

- [x] ~"group::package" reverts the increase of the GC review delay from 24h to 48h

- [ ] ~"group::package" stays alert for any reported issues with the migrated repositories. Address any issues/failures from the weekend (if any).

epic.title: Container Registry Phase 2 gradual production rollout

title: Match response attacks can have more than one matcher
description:
### Problem

Match response attacks send a HTTP request to the target website, and use matchers to determine if the attack successful. Some attack have different levels of success based on the response, which could potentially result in the finding having a different level of severity.

For example, check `78.1 OS Command Injection` could return `High` severity if it detected that a command ran successfully, and `Low` if it detected that the command ran with errors.

### Proposal

- Each `match_response_attack` can have multiple matchers
- Matchers should be evaluated in order of their definition (first defined, first evaluated)
- If one matcher matches, then a finding should be created using the level of severity defined in the match definition. The following matchers should not be evaluated.
- The description in the matcher should be appended to the end of the finding description (separated by a new line)


### Example definition

An example of what a matcher definition looks like is the following:

```yaml
matchers:
  - description: |
      This is a dangerous form of OS command injection
    severity: "High"
    match:
      type: "match"
      location: "response_body"
      expression: "..."
  - description: |
      The payload was not executed, but appears to be used
    severity: "Low"
    match:
      type: "match"
      location: "response_body"
      expression: "..."
```

### Implementation plan

- [x] ~~Update the parser to parse all of the match locations (if https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/367230 is complete)~~ (parsing is not complete)
- [x] Update `MatchResponseAttack` to accept multiple matchers, and determine an attack to be successful if any of the matchers match
- [x] Update `MatchResponseAttack` `IsSupported` to be supported if all matchers are supported
- [x] Ensure the finding is created using the severity defined by the matcher

title: Convert work_items_hierarchy FF to group actor
description:
See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/363447#note_1037620850

It would be more convenient if the `work_items_hierarchy` feature flag was checked against the group actor rather than project as it will now need to be tested alongside `work_items`, which is at the group level.

Both of these feature flags will need to be defaulted to `on` at the same time in order to release Tasks using the hierarchy widget.

title: Checks can match on response status
description:
### Problem

Certain attacks (e.g. [CWE-552](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/365418)) need to determine the success of an attack based on the response status.

### Proposal

Add a response status matcher to both Browserker and the DAST CWE checks schema.

### Implementation plan

- Build a `browserk.Matcher` matcher implementation that matches on response status
- The matcher should return `http_message_matcher.NotApplicableToMatch` if there is no response
- The matcher should accept a regular expression to match the status code on, e.g. `^20.$`
- On success, the matched value should contain the string value of the status code

epic.title: Browser-based DAST -  Active Attack Parity

title: Active attacks can inject into header values
description:
### Purpose

Injection locations should be created for header values in a request.

### Example 

A request with the following head:

```
GET /page/1 HTTP/1.1
User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE5.01; Windows NT)
Host: www.gitlab.com
Accept-Language: en-us
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Connection: Keep-Alive
```

Five injection locations should be created, one for `User-Agent`, `Host`, `Accept-Language`, `Accept-Encoding`, and `Connection`.

### Implementation plan

- Build an implementation of `browserk.InjectionLocation`, called `HeaderVauleInjectionLocation`.
- The new type should define a `Find...` method that returns an `browserk.InjectionLocationDetector`. This method should find all possible injection locations.
  - Add the Find method to the `InitializeInjectionLocationDetectionService` in DI
  - A header that has multiple values should be detected as a single injection location
- The `Modify` method should recreate the header. The `injection` should be used in place of the injection location's value. Update the `browserk.AttackRequest` with the new header value (ensuring previous values are removed).
- This must be very well unit tested, including both happy and sad paths.
- Please add an integration test (example: 
- `TestCheck22_1WithQueryParameterInjection`)

## Note: 
The scope of this issue is only `Header Value`. There will be separate issues for `Header Name` and `Appending/Deleting` a header.

### Reference

An example equivalent MR of adding a similar injection location is [Add query parameter injection location to active attacks](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/merge_requests/745)

epic.title: Add active check injection locations

title: [Spike] Migrate issue boards from Vuex+Apollo to Apollo only
description:
Currently, our boards implementation uses Vuex for state management and Apollo for the transport layer. This makes an application heavy (as we have more dependencies), the logic bloated (we need to do additional work for loading, error handling, and data updates), and the synchronization with the sidebar much harder (we need an events system to synchronize Vuex state of the boards with Apollo state of the sidebar). It also makes real-time boards harder to implement as we'll need to update the Vuex state manually on every subscription trigger.

### Proposal 

Instead of having two sources of truth, we should remove Vuex altogether and rely on Apollo cache exclusively to store boards data.

epic.title: Migrate issue boards from Vuex+Apollo to Apollo only

title: Support combining CE/EE aggregated metrics
description:
Plan stage recently added new aggregated metrics to track the features based on the base object Work Item shared among Plan groups (see: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346046.)

Although some service pings will be EE-only, we want to be able to aggregate both CE/EE service pings under the same aggregated metrics rather than adding and maintaining additional aggregated metrics:

> https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/362550#note_1042478747
> 
> I do not think it makes sense to have separate EE and CE aggregate counters. Then we have to join them if we ever want to see a combined count for both. There is also lots of things within work items that are using in both EE and CE, so we would have to basically add the same counter to yet another aggregate counter, which feels weird

> https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/362550#note_1042875043
> 
> ...that there's not too much value in separating them out. What would really provide value is to be able to use more granular events instead of aggregated counts, so we can run more advanced metrics. But that's way out of the scope of this :smile:

title: Frontend: Admin view instance-level environment variable has extra field "Environment scope"
description:
### Summary Admin view for CI/CD "Variables" has extra field `Environment scope` which is not applicable to **instance-level** environment variable. The field is grayed out and not changeable. The "question mark" help button is not clickable and does not have any link assigned. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create a Self-Managed GitLab instance 2. Go into **Admin** area 3. Create a new variable under **Settings => CI/CD => Variables => Expand => Add variable** - Pop-up window appear with the field `Environment scope` which is not applicable to the instance-level variable. (Screenshot below) ### Example Project Re-produceable on SaaS admin area or any Self-Managed instance Admin area ### What is the current *bug* behavior? `Environment scope` field is shown, however it is not applicable to the instance-level environment variable [Instance-level environment variable API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/instance_level_ci_variables.html) confirms that there is no "environment scope" key for the variable at the instance-level ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The field is hidden and not rendered in the UI ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![image](/uploads/8e1750a0f78686b8326f88d73db31709/image.png) ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes

title: Merged MR commit SHA is no longer clickable link
description:
### Summary
As shown in [MR 85708](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/85708) the SHA link generated on MR merge is no longer a link (screenshot provided below).

From a very brief discussion with @pedroms it seems this change is a regression and was unintended.

### Steps to reproduce
View any merged MR's Merge Details 

### Example Project
https://gitlab.com/m_lussier/test-project/-/merge_requests/2

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
Merge MR commit SHA is **not a clickable link** to navigate to commit page.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
Merge MR commit SHA is **a clickable link** to navigate to commit page.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
![Screen_Shot_2022-07-28_at_1.09.52_PM](/uploads/9ab90d16ef272f96493bfe774e3a2329/Screen_Shot_2022-07-28_at_1.09.52_PM.png)

title: Content Editor initial load is really slow because we are mounting too many Vue components
description:
### Summary

Rendering the Content Editor takes 600ms even when loading an empty document. I profiled the Content Editor Vue component using the Vue developer tools, and I found that if we remove a component like the code block bubble menu, the performance increases from 600ms to 200ms.

| With code block bubble menu | Without code block bubble menu |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2022-07-28_at_12.13.53_PM](/uploads/95e98454af437fc3873f02fa3504179b/Screen_Shot_2022-07-28_at_12.13.53_PM.png) | ![Screen_Shot_2022-07-28_at_12.18.35_PM](/uploads/1cd7e43942ceddfd0fa0f5c1057b6281/Screen_Shot_2022-07-28_at_12.18.35_PM.png) |

I had noticed this problem before, however, this performance bug was noticed by a maintainer during a code review unrelated to this problem. Addressing this problem is important for two reasons:

- The Content Editor is relatively isolated in the context of Wikis. This performance bug is more noticeable in the context of more complex features like issues and Merge Requests. 
- We will continue adding more Vue components to the Content Editor. We need to make sure that the Content Editor can scale to our future needs.

### Steps to reproduce

You can open the Content Editor in Wikis and notice the delay. 

### Possible fixes

- We should start by not rendering bubble menus unless they are active. 
- We should revisit other areas like the toolbar.

title: Partitioning Tooling: Add helper for creating zero partitions
description:
Building on the work done in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/89575+, we should add helpers that allow teams to convert their tables to zero partitions.

## Definition of done
- [ ] A migration helper is added that converts tables to zero partitions

epic.title: Add tools to support ci partitioning

title: Integrations leaking emails in WebHook Logs detail page
description:
### Summary While testing integrations' WebHook (`DroneCi`), I came across that some logs contain multiple commits data (author's email included and not redacted). ### Steps to reproduce 1. Go to the Integrations page of a project 2. Select an integration with a WebHook (e.g. DroneCi) and test the configuration 3. Click on `View details` of the webhook created 4. Scroll down to the request part and validate that emails are visible ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Committers' emails are visible ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The emails should be redacted ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![image](/uploads/fa802ee671701961125a33a679c51508/image.png) [Image redacted] ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes Update the `redact_author_email` method with the code bellow ```ruby def redact_author_email self.request_data.deep_transform_values! do |value| value =~ URI::MailTo::EMAIL_REGEXP ? _('[REDACTED]') : value end end ``` /cc @arturoherrero as the EM

title: Ignore project_id from requirements table
description:
Investigate if it is possible to ignore `project_id` on `requirements` table.  

Requirement proxy objects have a reference to `issue_id` which already has a reference to the project.  

In the current implementation, `Requirement#project_id` is needed to generate *iids* which could probably be
ignored, and then we use something like https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/snippets/2363823 to keep generating iids correctly with `Issue#project_id`. 

Follow up of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/358976

title: Old Metric Dictionary url not working
description:
## Problem 

Old Metric Dictionary URL not working.

We moved a project metrics dictionary from growth to the analytics section group
The project is using GitLab pages.

Is it possible to have a redirect of this URL https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/growth/product-intelligence/metric-dictionary/?data_category=operational to the new Metrics URL (https://metrics.gitlab.com/?q=operational)?

## Proposals

1. Add a redirect - Did not worked https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/analytics-section/product-intelligence/metric-dictionary/-/merge_requests/51
   - Create a redirect 
2. Move the project back under growth section - Did not worked, timing out https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369004#note_1044185607
   - revert the move
   - Create a [product-intelligence group under growth group](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/growth/product-intelligence)
   - Transfer project to a new product-intelligence group
   - concerns
      - In this case, do we move the product intelligence group with all the projects inside? 
      - or we could create a new product intelligence group under growth
      - will there be any other side effects on having a new group created 
3. Set up a page with GitLab pages with information and new link, this will be created under the same path as old project `growth/product-intelligence/metric-dictionary` in order to have the old URL available
   - in this page we can use javascript to redirect to the new page
     ```
       window.onload = function() {
         location.href = "https://metrics.gitlab.com/";
       }
     ```
   - concerns:
      - creating another project to maintain
      - will there be any other side effect on having a new project created under growth/product-intelligence group created?

  

I think we should encourage the usage of the custom URL https://metrics.gitlab.com/ instead of the URLs

title: [VSA] Support `label_name` instead of `label_id` for TasksByType service
description:
### Problem to solve

<!-- What is the user problem you are trying to solve with this issue? -->

The Tasks by Type API endpoint for VSA currently supports filtering based on the tokens in the VSA filter bar, but the label filtering does not align with the filter bar.

The filter bar uses `label_name` for filtering while the endpoint uses `label_id`, this results in:
- unnecessary work on the ~frontend when the page loads to extract the `label_id` for each label
- issues with selecting [multiple labels](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/258680#note_1037483041)

### Proposal

<!-- Use this section to explain the feature and how it will work. It can be helpful to add technical details, design proposals, and links to related epics or issues. -->

* ~backend [Update the task by type controller](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/controllers/groups/analytics/tasks_by_type_controller.rb#L27) to filter by `label_name` instead of `label_ids`
* ~backend Update the Tasks by type service to accept `label_name`

title: Bypass group SAML SSO enforcement for git access, using CI Job Token
description:
**[HackerOne report #1647721](https://hackerone.com/reports/1647721)** by `joaxcar` on 2022-07-23, assigned to @nmalcolm:

<details>
<summary>Click to expand H1 report. It describes known behaviour. Context is in [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368961#note_1043076641). </summary>

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

####  Summary

An owner/maintainer of a (premium +) top group can configure SAML SSO requirements for access to the group. See documentation [link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/saml_sso/). If the group activate the setting "Enforce SSO-only authentication for Git and Dependency Proxy activity for this group" any user that does not have an active SSO session with the configured provider is restricted from accessing the group projects through Git actions.

In the docs for "SSO enforcement" [link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/saml_sso/index.html#sso-enforcement) this is stated

> Credentials that are not tied to regular users (for example, project and group access tokens, and deploy keys) do not have the SSO check enforced. 

As far as I can read in the docs `CI Job Tokens` [link](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/jobs/ci_job_token.html) should not fall in this category as they are tied to the user that initialized the pipeline.

For me the SSO enforcement for git actions blocks all attempts to clone using authentications like `personal access tokens`, but if I run a pipeline job in any arbitrary project I can use the `CI_JOB_TOKEN` from that job to check out the repository that is protected by SSO.

First I thought that this might be related to the fix for SSO enforcement blocking pipeline schedules in the protected project (see [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/339888) and [MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/76909)). But this MR seems to use a check for server generated requests on the `http` schema, and not anything to do with CI tokens. The fix tries to open up access for pipelines running "inside the project".

A simple clone can be run like so:  
```yml  
data:  
  script:  git clone https://gitlab-ci-token:${CI_JOB_TOKEN}[@]gitlab.com/groupname/projectname.git ; ls ./hack  
```

####  Steps to reproduce

1. Create two users `owner01` and `attacker01`, log in as `owner01`  
2. Make sure the `owner01` user have `Ultimate` subscription. You can use a free trail on GitLab.com  
3. Create a `private` group `ultimate_group`  
4. Create a `private` project in the group called `project01` (make sure to have create README checked)  
5. Go to https://gitlab.com/groups/ultimate_group/-/group_members and invite `attacker01` as a `developer`  
6. Go to https://gitlab.com/groups/ultimate_group/-/saml  
7. Scroll down to configuration and check all checkboxes (Enable SAML, enforce SSO and enforce SSO for git) and add URL `https://example.com` and Certificate fingerprint `752c14ea195c369bac3c3b7896975ee9fd15eeb7` (the settings does not matter, we want it to fail on request)  
8. Click save  
9. Log out and log back in as `attacker01`  
10. Go to https://gitlab.com/-/profile/personal_access_tokens and generate a `personal access token`, take a note of the token  
11. Create a new project called `attack_project`  
12. Create a new file in the project called `.gitlab-ci.yml` and add (replace <PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN with the token)  
```yml  
data:  
  script:  git clone https://attacker01:<PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN>[@]gitlab.com/ultimate_group/project01.git ; ls ./project01  
```  
13. When the file is created a pipeline will run, check the logs for the pipeline job in the list at https://gitlab.com/attacker01/attack_project/-/jobs  
14. You should see an error message telling you that the checkout failed as there exists no SSO session for the user

`[Image redacted - a PAT was in the screenshot]`

15. Now go back and edit the pipeline file to (do not change anything except the project path)  
```yml  
data:  
  script:  git clone https://gitlab-ci-token:${CI_JOB_TOKEN}[@]gitlab.com/ultimate_group/project01.git ; ls ./project01  
```  
16. Check the new job in the pipeline job list and you should see that the git clone succeeded and the files from the project are listed

![clone2.jpg](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/4cfada07-e894-4ff5-b466-6ee84570ed8d/clone2.jpg)

####  Impact

A user that is restricted to access a project through Git actions due to SAML SSO enforcement can bypass this restriction and access the repository by requests using the CI job token. The user needs to have "gitlab access" to the project (the project is internal, or the user is added to the member list) but is blocked due to not using a SAML SSO login. Group owners might rely on SAML configurations and be relaxed with other access permissions as the SAML restrictions should block users. This is especially true for `internal` projects where the user can now access the repository through git.

####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

Using CI job tokens as authentication will allow cloning a repository that have SAML SSO git access restriction

####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Using CI job tokens should be checked against SAML SSO Sessions

####  Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

####  Impact

A user that is restricted to access a project through Git actions due to SAML SSO enforcement can bypass this restriction and access the repository by requests using the CI job token. The user needs to have "gitlab access" to the project (the project is internal, or the user is added to the member list) but is blocked due to not using a SAML SSO login. Group owners might rely on SAML configurations and be relaxed with other access permissions as the SAML restrictions should block users. This is especially true for `internal` projects where the user can now access the repository through git.

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

[REDACTED]

## How To Reproduce

Please add [reproducibility information] to this section:

1.
1.
1.

[reproducibility information]: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/security/#reproducibility-on-security-issues

</details>

## Proposal

Since this is expected behavior from a CI Job Token, we will instead be more descriptive in what the SSO enforcement for git activity provides, by rewording the description when enabling this option in the Group Settings:
> "Before enforcing SSO-only authentication for Git activity, enable SSO-only authentication for web activity."

To:
> "Before enforcing SSO-only authentication for users' Git activity, enable SSO-only authentication for web activity."


https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368961#note_1043076641

title: Add option to limit the number of assignees of a merge request
description:
Like #343362, the number of assignees is also uncapped. Since this fix should be fairly trivial if the work has already been done for reviewers, we could add this safeguard as well.

As mentioned in the related issue:

```
Having too many assignees could lead to potential performance problems. In addition, the user experience will degrade as we add more and more assignees.

This issue is to add a limit to the number of assignees that are allowed on a merge request.
```

title: Vulnerability status badge > Abstract into a reusable component
description:
The vulnerability details page renders the vulnerability status in its header:

![Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_11.53.55_AM](/uploads/be51ca87d93adcdfdf0976662f222c32/Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_11.53.55_AM.png)

While we have rendered similar status badges in other areas that deal with vulnerabilities, this occurrence seems to be the most robust as it supports different variants based on the status, and also localizes the status name.

To make it easier to benefit from the same logic, we should abstract this logic out into a reusable component. The code currently lives in the `ee/app/assets/javascripts/vulnerabilities/components/header.vue` component.

- [x] Create the `vulnerability-status-badge` component.
- [x] Move all the badge's logic out of `vulnerability` into this new component.
- [x] Make sure `header` renders the newly created `vulnerability-status-badge` component.

title: Shared vulnerability-details component > Prevent the false positive alert from inheriting Markdown styles
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/364781 we have added the false positive alert to the shared `ee/app/assets/javascripts/vulnerabilities/components/vulnerability_details.vue` component. This component wraps its content into a `div` that applies Markdown-specific styles with the `.md` class.

This makes the alert look off as its `h2` appears bigger than what it allowed by Pajamas:

![Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_12.01.19_PM](/uploads/00a4e0f0a7e063807bee66e543a29159/Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_12.01.19_PM.png)

We need to ensure that `.md` styles don't leak in the alert to achieve something like this:

![Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_12.02.15_PM](/uploads/a22056b0f5819b5d51d79840698f7e16/Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_12.02.15_PM.png)

- [x] Move the false positive alert out of the `.md` wrapper.

title: Shared vulnerability-details component > Add a way to show extra information in the modal only
description:
As part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8459, we are adding missing fields to the `ee/app/assets/javascripts/vulnerabilities/components/vulnerability_details.vue` component. Given that this component is used in the vulnerability page and the vulnerability modal (behind a feature flag currently), and that the vulnerability page already contains some of the information we're planning on adding, there is a need for a way to differentiate between both contexts in the component.

There are several valid approaches to address this, but we can start simple by implementing a boolean prop that we'll leverage to conditionally render fields with `v-if`.

- [ ] Add a `is-modal` prop.
- [ ] The prop is `false` by default.
- [ ] The modal renders the `vulnerability-details` with the `is-modal` prop enabled.

title: Gemnasium executes child pipelines when job of first stage fail
description:
### Summary

Merge request pipelines of Gemnasium move on to the child pipelines (for the three analyzers) even when jobs of first stage fail, and they're not allowed to fail. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/pipelines/598217255

This might impact branch pipelines as well. To be checked.

This impacts developers but does NOT impact users.

### Steps to reproduce

Create a MR pipeline where the go linter fails.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Child pipelines are executed.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Child pipelines should NOT be executed.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screenshot_2022-07-27_at_15.28.48](/uploads/8486524670438fcec083f44bbbe67077/Screenshot_2022-07-27_at_15.28.48.png)

### Possible fixes

Change the `when` param from `always` to `on_success`, in the rules of the `trigger`. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/363#note_1056788170


/cc @adamcohen @brytannia

title: Improve modal copy when deleting either the last or package files
description:
## Problem
When the user deletes all package files from a package, the modal copy is not very clear:
![Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_13.23.01](/uploads/70acd6d3a4578656ace0f4dde325d183/Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_13.23.01.png)

It may not be obvious to the user that deleting all files would delete the package.

## Solution

#### Update the body copy of the modal

| When the user deletes all files via a bulk delete action | When the user deletes the last file via individual delete action |
| ------ | ------ |
| Deleting the last package asset will remove version `0.0.0` of `package name` |  Deleting all package assets will remove version `0.0.0` of `package name` |

#### Update confirmation button of modal

![Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_13.26.26](/uploads/bb398d92c94677a01104bfb1daadb134/Screen_Shot_2022-07-27_at_13.26.26.png)

| Before | After |
| ------ | ------ |
| Delete | Permanently delete |


## Implementation guide

- Set text of modal based on condition https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/packages_and_registries/package_registry/pages/details.vue#L234

title: Projects list API slow param - search
description:
[During an investigation of the projects list API endpoint](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8164) we discovered that queries with the `search` parameter [have a slower than average response time](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8164#note_1024782021).

![Screen_Shot_2022-07-13_at_3.57.30_pm](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/uploads/6351a8c892423c5d3a60110b8a1b4b3b/Screen_Shot_2022-07-13_at_3.57.30_pm.png)

We should see if we can improve the performance of the endpoint when using this parameter.

### Availability and Testing
- Consider using a feature flag with this change, which will allow us to roll out and monitor any potential issues on staging and production. 
  - This would also trigger `package-and-qa-ff-disabled` and `package-and-qa-ff-enabled` jobs on the MR for functional regression tests, which can be checked for 500 errors, query timeouts, etc.
- No new GPT test needs to be added at this time, as GitLab is moving in the direction to use Advanced Search for projects search (see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368879#note_1067154075)

Feel free to reach out to:
- @vburton for any questions on functional testing, QA failures, etc.
- The Quality Enablement team for running any additional performance tests needed

title: MR Widget Extension Telemetry - `WidgetStatusChecks`
description:
## What

We need to implement metrics instrumentation around each of the events that widgets in the Widget Extension framework automatically report.

## How

Follow the steps [documented here](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/new_fe_guide/modules/widget_extensions.html#add-new-widgets).  
Note the mention of the `--ee` flag.

## When

There isn't a huge amount of urgency for this, but it would be nice to have sooner rather than later.

Events that aren't included in metrics are [reported as errors](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368651) by our backend system.  
To avoid needing to [disable telemetry entirely](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93330) for widgets that are not instrumented, we should just instrument them all.  
Notably, these errors [are not causing problems](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C01EMBKS5DW/p1658889380078289?thread_ts=1658888310.073319&cid=C01EMBKS5DW) (internal slack link), but they are noisy.

## Why

Other than to increase the telemetry information we receive by default from widgets, _why_ this way is because this is how we track metrics with Redis.

## Other info

You might find it useful to look at the 4 CE widgets that have already been addressed in the MRs below.  
Each was done by following the steps in the documentation linked above.

| Issue/MR | Widget | EE? |
| -------- | ------ | --- |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/91831 | `WidgetTestSummary` | :x: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93340 | `WidgetTerraform` | :x: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93333 | `WidgetCodeQuality` | :x: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93232 | `WidgetAccessibility` | :x: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368871 | `WidgetSecurityReports` | :white_check_mark: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368872 | `WidgetBrowserPerformance` | :white_check_mark: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368873 | `WidgetLicenseCompliance` | :white_check_mark: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368874 | `WidgetLoadPerformance` | :white_check_mark: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368875 | `WidgetMetrics` | :white_check_mark: |
| We are here :point_right_tone1: | `WidgetStatusChecks` | :white_check_mark: |

epic.title: MR Widget - Update telemetry on all widgets

title: MR Widget Extension Telemetry - `WidgetLicenseCompliance`
description:
## What

We need to implement metrics instrumentation around each of the events that widgets in the Widget Extension framework automatically report.

## How

Follow the steps [documented here](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/new_fe_guide/modules/widget_extensions.html#add-new-widgets).  
Note the mention of the `--ee` flag.

## When

There isn't a huge amount of urgency for this, but it would be nice to have sooner rather than later.

Events that aren't included in metrics are [reported as errors](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368651) by our backend system.  
To avoid needing to [disable telemetry entirely](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93330) for widgets that are not instrumented, we should just instrument them all.  
Notably, these errors [are not causing problems](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C01EMBKS5DW/p1658889380078289?thread_ts=1658888310.073319&cid=C01EMBKS5DW) (internal slack link), but they are noisy.

## Why

Other than to increase the telemetry information we receive by default from widgets, _why_ this way is because this is how we track metrics with Redis.

## Other info

You might find it useful to look at the 4 CE widgets that have already been addressed in the MRs below.  
Each was done by following the steps in the documentation linked above.

| Issue/MR | Widget | EE? |
| -------- | ------ | --- |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/91831 | `WidgetTestSummary` | :x: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93340 | `WidgetTerraform` | :x: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93333 | `WidgetCodeQuality` | :x: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93232 | `WidgetAccessibility` | :x: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368871 | `WidgetSecurityReports` | :white_check_mark: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368872 | `WidgetBrowserPerformance` | :white_check_mark: |
| We are here :point_right_tone1: | `WidgetLicenseCompliance` | :white_check_mark: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368874 | `WidgetLoadPerformance` | :white_check_mark: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368875 | `WidgetMetrics` | :white_check_mark: |
| https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368876 | `WidgetStatusChecks` | :white_check_mark: |

title: Update marked javascript package from 0.3.12 to 4.0.18
description: Issue created from vulnerability 32191286 `marked` is also in this vulnerability: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/security/vulnerabilities/32191285 I presume that `marked`, being a markdown parser, receives and parses input from our users. I can't see us calling the methods in the description explicitly, but the PoC makes it look as though the attack is fairly simple. If we aren't vulnerable we can downgrade this. ### Description: The regular expression `block.def` and `inline.reflinkSearch` may cause catastrophic backtracking against some strings and lead to a regular expression denial of service (ReDoS). Anyone who runs untrusted markdown through a vulnerable version of marked and does not use a worker with a time limit may be affected. This issue is patched As a workaround, avoid running untrusted markdown through marked or run marked on a worker thread and set a reasonable time limit to prevent draining resources. * Severity: high * Confidence: unknown * Location: [yarn.lock](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/e79a78747e94bba5cac4d1c86f8c5ca2f6b14581/yarn.lock) A PoC from the GitHub Advisory: ```js import * as marked from 'marked'; console.log(marked.parse(`[x]: x \\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](\\[\\](`)); ``` ### Solution: Upgrade to version 4.0.10 or above. ### Identifiers: * [Gemnasium-dc02f221-a495-47d1-9841-0b4dbd4a2ba3](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/gemnasium-db/-/blob/master/npm/marked/CVE-2022-21680.yml) * [CVE-2022-21680](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2022-21680) * [GHSA-rrrm-qjm4-v8hf](https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-rrrm-qjm4-v8hf) ### Links: * https://github.com/markedjs/marked/commit/c4a3ccd344b6929afa8a1d50ac54a721e57012c0 * https://github.com/markedjs/marked/releases/tag/v4.0.10 * https://github.com/markedjs/marked/security/advisories/GHSA-rrrm-qjm4-v8hf * https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2022-21680 ### Scanner: * Name: Gemnasium

title: Add `container_scanning` directive in agent config file
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Problem to solve

Considering that we are no longer using Starboard for [Operational Container Scanning](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/clusters/agent/vulnerabilities.html), it no longer makes sense to use term `starboard` in the agent config file.

### Proposal

<!-- Use this section to explain the feature and how it will work. It can be helpful to add technical details, design proposals, and links to related epics or issues. -->

1. The term `container_scanning` will be added as an alternate option instead of using the term `starboard` in the definition for the agent config file.
   1. Note: We we will continue to support `starboard` in the code through %16.0 as this will be a breaking change.
1. Documentation will be updated to reflect this change.


### Implementation Plan

- [x] Update [agentcfg.proto](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/blob/c33e770b7e33b926a73cfc8221f50a99b8c31496/pkg/agentcfg/agentcfg.proto) to add `container_scanning` similar to `starboard`
- [x] Update [internal/module/starboard_vulnerability/agent/module.go](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/blob/c33e770b7e33b926a73cfc8221f50a99b8c31496/internal/module/starboard_vulnerability/agent/module.go) to get `container_scanning` from `agentcfg.AgentConfiguration` and if it's empty fallback to `starboard`
- [-] For consistency, update the name of the directory from [internal/module/starboard_vulnerability](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/cluster-integration/gitlab-agent/-/tree/master/internal/module/starboard_vulnerability) to `internal/module/container_scanning` and update the references
- [x] ~documentation Update documentation to mention the `starboard` field will not be supported from %"16.0"

title: Issues::CreateService should embed permission checks
description:
## Problem

While reviewing https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/92146 I realized that `Issues::CreateService` does not embed the permission check `can?(user, :create_issue, project)`.

This makes it unsafe to use this service object since it's supposed to be an application-level service but permissions checks are missing. In fact today we do have to execute the permission check before running this service. We do it in most of the places but I found at least one place where we don't seem to check for permissions (if I'm understanding the code correctly):

`IncidentManagement::PagerDuty::CreateIncidentIssueService --> IncidentManagement::Incidents::CreateService --> Issues::CreateService`

This chain of services is executed without permissions checks.

## Proposal

Embed the permission check inside the service object so it can be safely used by other contexts like `IncidentManagement` and we don't need to duplicate the permission check everywhere we use the service object, like for quick actions, REST API, GraphQL, controller, etc.

title: Creating FOSS Auditor for authentication audit events
description:
### Problem to solve
Currently authentication events are generated using AuditEventService, as we want to have one auditing framework to avoid confusions which is Auditor we would like to move these events to Auditor itself.

Currently AuditEventService is present in `app/services/audit_event_service.rb` and also inside ee `ee/app/services/ee/audit_event_service.rb` which enables us to create audit events without having EE license as for authentication events we do not need EE License.

But for Auditor we only have code inside ee `ee/lib/gitlab/audit/auditor.rb` also the build service it uses to create audit event only has code in ee `ee/app/services/audit_events/build_service.rb` 

### Proposal

1. Make Auditor class in `lib/gitlab/audit` which handles authentications events only.
2. Make build service in `app/services/audit_events/build_service.rb` which builds audit event. for this step I think we can directly move majority of the code from `ee/app/services/audit_events/build_service.rb` to `app/services/audit_events/build_service.rb`.
3. Migrate existing authentication events which are using `AuditEventService` to use `Auditor`.
